segments.text: How did you meet Picard?
Well, I met Picard when I was with O&R, and he had been invited to London to talk about the Baptist Captriest and to the scientific society.
I guess it was the Royal Society of

marine engineer or something like that, and so I made a habit of attending these various meetings of this type, and at that time I met him, and we had brief discussion after the meeting, and I asked him to join me the next next day, and we, at that time, we had lunch and talked over the whole plan and more or less developed this idea that this is something that I would attempt to try to
to organize and sell this program to the Navy.
And that's how it began.
It involved working with people back in Washington and what we call Code 416, Gordon Mill, Martin Maxwell, people like that who were in the oceanographic group there.
And also at that time there was a

symposium meeting in Washington and it was possible to fly Picard over and have him give his presentation in Washington and at this meeting we came up with a resolution this was a civilian meeting but about more or less oceanographic and Navy science and we passed a revolution which

by this meaning that the Navy should get involved in the Bathyscaphe Trieste and in deep submergence, and this is more or less a resolution you could carry around and say, well, this group has favored this proposal, and you could talk to the higher brass, and who were generally receptive, but it's a matter of a lot of footwork and knowing people to get something moving.
And mainly this seed money from ONR to get...
Did you keep up with the Trieste after it was purchased by the Navy?
Were you involved in any of its later activities?
Well, I was involved to the point where it was transferred, purchased by the Navy, and shipped back to San Diego to the Navy Electronics Laboratory.
And we had, at that time, we began these series of dives, testing and so forth, off San Diego.
And it was my understanding that I would be the chief scientist in charge of this project.
However, this didn't go in that direction.
Eventually, I was somewhat delayed in getting back from
When I came back to NAL, a person named Reckonser had been placed in charge of the project, and I was a consultant to the project, but I didn't really have control of it.
I was involved with the project, but I didn't have quite the control that I wanted to have.
But I was involved with the project through the time when we made the
dive, a seven-mile dive in a Challenger Deep.
So I was involved with the team, involved with the Challenger Deep dive.
I guess most of this is probably described pretty well in that book that Picard and I wrote called Seven Miles Down.
Right.
Would you consider the Trieste your most important activity while you were at NEAL?
Well, I wrote my first paper, I guess, on sea floor spreading at NEL.
And I think my early ideas on continental drift and plate tectonics, what is now called plate tectonics, were perhaps more important.
But certainly the deep submergence aspect was important because it was...
It doesn't show up because there really aren't any publications from it except this book and a few papers.
But so far as playing an important role, sort of being a catalyst and getting the Navy involved in deep submergence, I think that was a very important thing, the triage work.
Describe how you came up with your theory of the formation of the Gulf of Mexico through rifting.
You're speaking of seafloor spreading.
Well, that's much later.
Once this idea of what we now call plate tectonics was pretty well established in my
in my mind.
And it was pretty well made, obsolete all older models of global tectonics.
And aside from the problems of the major dispersion of continents, there were the problems involved in the development of the Caribbean and the Gulf of Mexico.
And any model you had, four of these

The peripheral aspects of the breakup of Pangea had to be solved, and also they had to be solved in terms of plate tectonic rules, that you're permitted to have rifts and large shifts, which by older geology was not really allowable to move things in horizontal directions for great distances, and to explain things mainly in terms of rotation and drifting.
Of course, the first person who took that great liberty in this sort of field was Maureen Carey in Tasmania in the late 1950s.

And so once she more or less sort of broke this field, we all were involved in what are now regarded as sort of wild schemes to explain such things as the Gulf of Mexico, which apparently were these schemes we envisioned where
certainly not quite correct, they were the right type of solution, were going in the right direction.
And so we got answers which were not exactly correct, but more or less in the proper ballpark.
When, as one of the early workers, if I may say so, with plate tectonics,
When did you first begin to contemplate the possibility of continental drift and plate tectonics?
Well, in the early days of marine geology, there were endless surprises.
And these surprises were
such things that the thickness of the ocean sediments was only one-tenth of what it should be if the ocean's basins were as old as the world.
And the seamounts were not, when we dredged them, as we did on Operation High Jump with the work of Ed Hamilton, but we went out there with the intention of
dredging the seamounts and dredging up fossils.

Well, this was a rather a bizarre approach because you wouldn't think that, I mean, if you were flying through an airplane here, you wouldn't think of dropping a dredge in the ground and getting fossils you could recognize.
But we thought we could do this.
I mean, we thought there was sufficient rationale to do this.
And in fact, we succeeded beautifully.
We got a beautiful collection of macro fossils, resisted and so forth, too.
demonstrate these geos were not pre-Cambrian, very ancient seamounts, as Harry Hess had supposed, but were indeed very young, Cretaceous.
So this was, again, another surprise.
And when you have enough surprises, you can't be surprised unless you have preconceived notion or preconceived model.
If you have no ideas at all, then there are no surprises.
But if you have ideas and they're wrong, then you're surprised by what you find.
So when you have enough surprises, you begin to suspect the whole model.
And in 52, then, I went to 53, I went to Japan for a year as a Fulbright Fellow.
And I began to work on some of the results there in the Japanese Hydrographic Office, particularly on the Northwest Pacific region.
the Japanese had developed this very nice hydrographic chart from their wartime data, and I revised this slightly and published it and tried to describe the whole northwest Pacific.
Well, it became apparent to me that there was a certain hierarchy of features on the ocean floor, and in this hierarchy, the most important features, the number one, the dominant features, were
well, first of all, the continents and ocean basins were the primary features in the world.
But beyond that, then it was the trenches.
The trenches transected everything else.
Once you crossed a trench, you had a whole new type of geology.
And so in thinking about this and looking at some of the seamount change, which appeared to be diving into the trenches, I just began to think that that
under-threshing was taking place, and these seamounts were being consumed in the trenches, and this was a form of continental drift.
So I went to a continental drift model, which I did then at that time in about 1952, and I guess it became a bit apparent in my GSA paper in 1954.
I didn't discuss continental drift as such.
that I guess that's when I first became convinced of the reality of under-thrusting and drift on a small scale.

It wasn't until later when we, after the mid-ocean ridges were recognized and the rift was recognized, when it became apparent that you had a model that would run if you generated no ocean floor in the mid-ocean rifts.
And this was a conveyor belt thing.
And this was a process which I termed seafloor spreading, which is a process which is now, the word is still retained, although it's not really a good description.
I couldn't think of it.
I didn't like that expression to begin with.
I searched for something better.

use that use that term and the concept of seafloor spreading is still uh of course it's still the term is still used uh so it's it's really in tokyo then in 53 when you begin to put all put the pattern together yes that's right now a tokyo experience is very interesting because i arrived there and i uh i did uh
several things.
I had the first scuba equipment in Japan.
I arrived there with an underwater diving apparatus.
I did a good deal of diving in various parts of Japan, including the pearl beds and some of the sacred fishing grounds.
The Japanese had never seen self-contained breathing apparatus before, so this was quite a remarkable thing to them.

Second thing I was concerned with in Japan is I, just before I went there, we had this Navy had installed this SOFAR system, experimentally, and we received some explosions on the hydrophones off California, and
At that time, fishing boats had reported an eruption on San Benedicto Island in the Riviera Lajos off Mexico.
And the fishermen had reported this, but of course you often see cloud plumes on tops of islands and there are often false reports of eruptions.
There was sufficient evidence here to justify looking into it further, and I found at the same time these explosions had been arriving in the SOFAR system.
And it turns out later that these SOFAR, these noises were not from Mexico, but were from Myojin Sho off Japan.
They had traveled some 8,000 kilometers beneath the sea, and they were shielded from the receiving station
in Oahu, but they were received in these two stations off California at Puerto Narguero and I guess Mendocino, something like that.
So we had a line of position because we could see eventually that these signals arrived from Japan.
But in the meantime, this aroused sufficient interest in the eruptions off Mexico to justify trying to investigate that.
And this is sort of an interesting exercise in trying to get something done.
Because we tried to get the Coast Guard to fly down, and they were limited to flying 1,000 miles.
This was 1,200 miles away, just beyond their limit.
We couldn't get the Navy to act.
The Navy wouldn't dispatch any flights, mainly because we had to go through channels.
And we were not allowed to bypass, you know, we did all the time, but we were not supposed to bypass any channels.
And when you go through channels, if you go through, say, four channels to reach some person, your chances of receiving a no answer go up each time.
So it's sort of a geometric thing.
The man right above you might say yes or no, but...
If you go through this yes or no process four times, your chances are one to one to the fourth power, or two to the fourth power, or one to 16.
So anyway, we couldn't get the Navy to act.
So Gifford Ewing, at that time, he made a long distance call to the Navy, to the Air Force somewhere, and the Air Force
had weather flights.
And so although we were naval scientists, we got the Air Force to cooperate with us and get aboard and divert a weather reconnaissance flight to go down and see this alleged eruption.
And sure enough, it was a major eruption.
It was a new volcano being formed, which is a rather remarkable event on this island.
And this was just before I went to Japan.
It turned out later that these noises we heard were not from the sound, but were from Japan.

So this became a major project with me while in Japan to investigate the Myojin Sho eruption and the underwater transmission of sound associated with that eruption, which was remarkable also because it involved the loss of a ship being blown up by this eruption.
In fact, the scientist I was supposed to work with in Japan was lost.
He was the chief scientist on the ship from the Hydrographic Office of Japan, which was sent down to investigate this eruption.
And the entire ship disappeared from the world, including 31 chief scientists and 31 other people.
And all that was found was a life preserver and a few planks which had embedded in them bits of volcanic rock.
So the ship had been destroyed by a volcanic explosion.
And on the SOFAR records, we had the explosion pinpointed.
There was one explosion on, I guess it was September 23, 1952, at 1231 in the afternoon.
And that is obviously the explosion that the ship got there.
And this new island had sunk.
And all there was, presumably, was discolored water.
And they just went over the top of it.
At that time, the
The volcano rather than exploding every hour or so, it was maybe exploding once a day.
It was in its dying, waning stages.
But the ship went up into the discolored water and was blown up, engulfed by the explosion.
And then it's after you leave Japan then that you go to London.
Yes, I was back then in the West Coast for six months or so.
Then I went to London from return to the New Electronics Laboratory.
and then went to ONR London for four years.
Okay, and then from London you come back to the NEL lab.
Yes, that's right.
Okay.
And had there been any change in the emphasis of the work of the lab by the time you returned from London?
Did they seem to be more mission-oriented than they had been before, if that were possible?
They became perhaps more mission-oriented.
They were...
in a sense, but the Korean War was over, and during the Korean War time, of course, we were highly mission-oriented.

But oceanography had a bit of a brighter, it was becoming sort of a darling science, and so it received more support, particularly the physical oceanography, but the field of marine geology and geophysics received, again, almost none.
We really were not better off than before.
It was a very minimal sort of support.
We were the most visible group of oceanographers, I think, in the entire Navy because we were doing a lot of good work and publishing many papers.
We had a very, very fine group in those days.
Then in 1963, you go to NOAA.
In 63, I left and went to Washington, that's right, to NOAA, which was then the Coast and Geodetic Survey.
At that time, the Coast Survey, well, a few years prior, they had hired Harris Stewart, who's now our director here, and he had had a Ph.D. from Scripps and was also a student of Shepard's.

and I guess he was their instrumental but the Coast Survey suddenly also became rather science-oriented for many years they were prior to that they were not and people in the Coast Survey who had did any any publication at all were few and far between there was Gibson and Jordan and these people just wrote their scientific papers at night they kind of
did all this work, they weren't allowed to do any sort of scientific work in their normal mission.

But this began to change in the late 50s, and then in the early 60s, the Coast Survey organized what they, what was called a, it was sort of a scientific staff, which was supposed to, which had as a mission to do scientific work.
basic research.
We were sort of a consulting staff.
And I was asked by Stuart to come and join that group, and so I did at that time.
This was beginning of sort of the scientific involvement of the...
The co-survey was very hidebound, very traditional organization.
And they were
by law, they could not investigate, they only could investigate the continental shelf by congressional terms of reference.
And this is partly a matter, I guess, of jealousy between services as to who does what.
Now the world was divided up between the hydrographic office and the co-survey.
And the co-survey,
extended their mission a little bit.
They defined the shelf as extending to 2,000 fathoms, so they could at least investigate the continental slope.
But their main mission was making hydrographic surveys, and they didn't really bother to even contour up their boat sheets.
And this is what, for example, Sherford was doing in the early days.
He was taking this basic data.
And, well, for many years, the close survey

ran lines of sounding across the Gulf of Alaska and up to the Alaskan region for some 20 years or so, and they had these lines of soundings, but it remained for Bill Menard and I to make a bathymetric map.
They didn't ever bother to make a bathymetric map of their deep sea data, so they had this single mission of
of collecting soundings and making nautical charts, but not extending their work beyond that.
Is NOAA too big or too small?
NOAA?
Well, it's a little hard to say.
We're, of course, something called the
environmental research laboratories, of which we are one of perhaps a dozen.
And I saw something a few years ago indicating there were something over 600, 700 scientists, people who were labeled as in one way or another being in the scientific category.
Now I suppose that number might be close to 1,000, a bit more even.
No, it's not too big.
I guess everyone has their ideas about how things should be organized or reorganized.
I think from where I sit in the field of marine geology, we think that the, well, we think in the NOAA, the ocean side of NOAA has been
not emphasized enough.
It's the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, but it's mainly become a super weather bureau.
The weather, the meteorology part is much more important than the oceanic part.
And the main, of course, laboratories in oceanography are this laboratory, the main one, plus a smaller group in Seattle.
And even within the oceanography, we really don't do the things that I wish we
had or could do that's involved in deep ocean.
And we're doing almost nothing in the deep ocean.
And for many years, we were sort of more or less competing with the geological survey to be the lead agency for the government in marine geology and geophysics.
And I think mainly by...

lack of funding, lack of action, the U.S. National Survey has moved into that role, which perhaps is what it should be, but we always hoped that we would, since we do have many things in our favor, we have an officer corps and we have the ships, and we have ships which have ocean keeping and deep sea capabilities, we feel it should be involved in deep sea missions which are
proper for the types of ships we have.
We have, say, Class I oceanographic vessels.
The only program we have going now is Peter Rona's program in marine geology on the Mid-Atlantic Raids, the TAG program.
